Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Situation2: Most callers are receptive, and occasional simple questions arise that the script already covers.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to dial the next number on my call list. It was Jamie, my best friend, and I could hear the strain in their voice before they even finished saying hello. “Can you talk? I really need someone right now,” Jamie said, voice trembling. I glanced at the clock—my shift had just started, and the call queue was already filling up. As a telemarketer, I was expected to be on every call, ready to answer questions and handle objections smoothly, following the script to the letter. But as a friend, I knew Jamie needed me to listen, to be present, to offer comfort and support. My supervisor’s voice echoed in my mind, reminding me of the importance of every call, every sale. At the same time, Jamie’s words tugged at my heart, making it impossible to ignore their pain. I stared at my headset, torn between the demands of my job and the needs of my friend, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
